Box 14115-4838TehranIslamic Republic of Irangrid.419140.90000000106900331Division of Polymer Science and TechnologyResearch Institute of Petroleum Industry (RIPI)P.O. Box 14665-1998TehranIslamic Republic of Iran+98-21-8011001+98-21-8009730morsali_a@modares.ac.ir231220106201121235235931220101972010212201023122010© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20102010Abstract

Nanorods of the three-dimensional coordination polymer, [Ag2(μ2-py-4-c)2]n (1) [py-4-c− = pyridine-4-carboxylate], have been synthesized by sonochemical process. The single-crystal X-ray data of compound 1 shows the formation of a 3D interpenetrated silver(I) coordination polymer, which has agostic interactions around the silver(I) ions and two types of AgI ions with O2NAg1···O2H, N2Ag2···O2H2 coordination spheres. Silver nanoparticles were fabricated from thermal decomposition of 1 nanorods. These nanostructures were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The thermal stability of 1 was studied by thermo gravimetric (TG) and differential thermal (DT) analysis.

Coordination polymers are a very important topic of modern solid-state chemistry. Especially porous compounds like MOF-5 [1], MIL-53 [2] or HKUST-1 [3] have attracted attention due to their potential as heterogeneous catalysts or adsorbents for gases like hydrogen. Besides porosity, there are also attractive aspects of non-porous coordination polymers such as magnetic, luminescent, vaporochromism or conducting properties, to name a few [4–6]. Coordination polymers offer significant advantages over conventional molecular compounds due to very low solubility in conventional solvents and much higher thermal stability. They also have applications as sensors, organic light emitting diodes and full-colored LCD displays [7].

Among the polymeric coinage d10 metal complexes, silver(I) coordination polymers have received much attention because silver(I) shows a tendency to form coordination polymers with unique metal–carbon [8–12] and metal–metal [13, 14] interactions. However, agostic (Ag···H–C) interactions are rare [15–17]. Over the past decade, several coordination polymeric networks of Ag+ have been synthesized and investigated. In contrast, examples of nano-scale structures of Ag+ coordination polymers are scarce [18–20]. Thus, their preparation is desirable in order to tailor their physical and chemical properties [21]. On the other hand, metallic silver has been extensively used in a variety of applications; e.g., catalysis, electronics, photonics, photography, biology and medical science, due to its unique properties. For example, silver has the highest electrical conductivity, thermal conductivity and reflectivity of all metals [22]. It is also well known that Tl+ and Ag+ compounds are similar in structure and chemical properties [23]. As a continuation of our previous studies on supramolecular compounds of these metal centers [24–34] and to have a comparison between coordination modes of these metal centers with similar ligands, we wish to report a three-dimensional coordination polymer of Ag+ with a pyridine-4-carboxylate (py-4-c−) ligand. In addition to the synthesis and characterization of a three-dimensional Ag+ nano-coordination polymer (NCP) of pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (Hpy-4-c) by the sonochemical process [19, 20, 35, 36], silver nanoparticles were fabricated by thermal decomposition in oleic acid (OA) [37].

ExperimentalMaterials and Physical Techniques

All reagents for synthesis and analysis were commercially available and used as received. Double distilled water was used to prepare aqueous solutions. An ultrasonic bath (Tecna 6; 50–60 Hz and 0.138 KW) was used for ultrasonic irradiation. Melting points were measured on an Electrothermal 9100 apparatus and were uncorrected. Microanalyses were carried out using a Heraeus CHN-O-Rapid analyzer. IR spectra were recorded using Perkin-Elmer 597 and Nicolet 510P spectrophotometers. The thermal behavior was measured with a PL-STA 1500 apparatus between 35 and 600 °C in a static nitrogen atmosphere. Crystallographic measurements were made using a Bruker APEX area-detector diffractometer. The intensity data were collected using graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (wavelength = 0.71073 Å). The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2. Structure solution and refinement were accomplished using SHELXL-97 program packages [38]. The molecular structure plot and simulated XRD powder pattern based on single crystal data were prepared using Mercury software [39]. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed using a Philips X’pert diffractometer with monochromatized Cu-kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). The samples were characterized by a scanning electron microscope with gold coating.

Synthesis of [Ag<sub>2</sub>(<italic>μ</italic><sub>2</sub>-py-4-c)<sub>2</sub>]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> (<bold>1</bold>) and Preparation of Its Single Crystals

In CH3CN (20 mL) pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (0.246 g, 2 mmol) was mixed and stirred with a solution of KOH (0.114 g, 2 mmol) in H2O (3 mL) to form a clear solution. Addition of AgNO3 (0.340 g, 2 mmol) in CH3CN (5 mL) produced a clear solution. The resulting solution was stirred for 2 h and then allowed to stand for several days in the dark at room temperature to evaporate the solvent and form crystals. Suitable brown crystals for single crystal X-ray analysis were washed with acetone and air dried, d.p. = 230 °C, Yield: 0.550 g (68% based on final product). IR (selected bands; in cm−1): 670s, 688s, 761s, 830w, 864w, 1028w, 1053w, 1144w, 1228s, 1282s, 1365vs, 1413s, 1546s, 1604s and 1729s. Anal. calcd. (%) for C12H8Ag2N2O4: C, 35.47; H, 1.97; N, 6.90; found (%): C, 34.85; H, 2.08; N, 6.72.

Synthesis of [Ag<sub>2</sub>(<italic>μ</italic><sub>2</sub>-py-4-c)<sub>2</sub>]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> Nanorods by Sonochemical Process

To prepare nanostructures of compound 1 by sonochemical process, an ultrasonic bath with different concentrations of metal and ligand solutions (0.05, 0.10 and 0.15 M) were used. The mixture was subjected to a power level of 0.138 KW for 1 h. To the prepared ligand (Kpy-4-c) solution in double distilled water (50 mL), a proper volume of aqueous AgNO3 solution (50 mL) was added drop-wise under ultrasonic irradiation. The precipitate was filtered, washed with double distilled water and then dried; Found (%): C, 35.82; H, 1.89; N, 7.02%). IR (selected bands; in cm−1): 671s, 686s, 763s, 830w, 865w, 1027w, 1055w, 1144w, 1229s, 1282s, 1365vs, 1414s, 1548s, 1601s and 1731s. To obtain silver nanostructures, compound 1 nanorods was calcinated at 823 K in a furnace and air atmosphere for 5 h.

Synthesis of Silver Nanoparticles by Thermal Decomposition in Oleic Acid as a Surfactant

To prepare silver nanoparticles in oleic acid (OA), compound 1 nanorods (406 mg, 1.0 mmol) was dispersed in OA (8 mL, 25 mmol) to form a homogenous emulsion. This solution was degassed for 15 min and then heated to 543 K for 1 h in an electric furnace. A black precipitate was formed. A small amount of toluene and a large excess of EtOH was added to the reaction solution. The metallic silver was separated by centrifugation and washed with EtOH.

Results and DiscussionStructure Description

Scheme 1 shows the reaction between silver(I) nitrate and pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (Hpy-4-c) by two different methods. The reaction between pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (Hpy-4-c) and silver(I) nitrate provided a crystalline material with the general formula [Ag2(μ2-py-4-c)2]n (1). Structure determination of compound 1 by X-ray crystallography (Tables 1, 2) showed the complex to be a novel interpenetrated three-dimensional polymer (Fig. 1). Two types of silver atoms exist in compound 1; three-coordinate Ag1 atoms with disordered T-shape AgO2N coordination sphere and two-coordinate Ag2 atoms with linear AgN2 coordination sphere (Fig. 2, up and middle). The py-4-c− ligand acts as a μ2-bridging ligand where one oxygen atom of carboxylate group and the pyridine nitrogen atom of this ligand coordinate to two silver atoms (Fig. 2, down). The structure was analyzed for close Ag···O and Ag···H secondary interactions. It appears that Ag1 atoms in compound 1 have two close contacts with O1 and O2 oxygen atoms (Ag1–O1 = 3.148 and Ag1–O2 = 3.088 Ǻ) and Ag2 atoms have also two weak secondary interactions with O2 atoms (Ag2–O2 = 2.824 Ǻ). The closest Ag–O interaction in compound 1 are longer than the Ag–O distances in similar complexes (i.e., 2.248(4), 2.279(5), 2.408(2), 2.576(2) and 2.639(2) Ǻ) [40–43] and shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radius of Ag and O (3.24 Ǻ) (van der Waals radius of Ag and O are 1.72 and 1.52 Å respectively, see [44]). On the other hand it appears that the silver ions may be involved in Ag···H–C interactions between the silver atoms and the hydrogen atoms of the py-4-c− ligand (Fig. 2, up and middle). Ag1 with a Ag(1)–H(8) distance of 2.781 Å and Ag2 with two Ag(2)–H(4) distances of 2.749 Å. The reported M···H distances for silver involved agostic interactions are 2.823, 2.706, 2.657, 2.776, 2.731 and 2.585 Ǻ [15–17]. Thus Ag2 atoms in compound 1 with linear AgN2 coordination sphere have four secondary interactions in the equatorial plane, finally forming approximately octahedral arrangement around AgI ion (Fig. 2, middle). Figure 3, up and down show the structure of compound 1 along the crystallographic b and c axis, respectively. As could be observed from these figures compound 1 has some vacant pores which may be initially thought that compound 1 is a porous coordination polymer, but more structural considerations indicate that these pores are occupied by other interpenetrating networks, result in a completely packed coordination polymer with no vacant sites.

Figure 4a shows the simulated XRD pattern from single crystal X-ray data of the compound 1 and Fig. 4b shows the XRD pattern of a typical sample of [Ag2(μ2-py-4-c)2]n (1) prepared by sonochemical process. Acceptable match, with slight difference in 2θ, were observed between the simulated from single-crystal X-ray data pattern (Fig. 4a) and its from the experimental powder X-ray diffraction pattern for nanostructures obtained by sonochemical process (Fig. 4b). The results of XRD powder study indicate that the experimental data are in good agreement with the simulated XRD powder pattern based on single crystal data, hence the obtained compound is as a mono-phase. The morphology and size of the samples prepared by sonochemical process were investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Figures 5, 6 and 7 indicate the original morphology of the nanorods prepared by sonochemical process. The corresponding particle size distribution histogram of these nanorods could be observed in Figs. 5, 6 and 7. As could be observed from these figures, when concentration increases from 0.05 M (Fig. 5) to 0.15 M (Fig. 7), smaller nanorods with the average diameter of 2.212 μm, 626 nm and 239 nm was formed. This phenomenon was also observed in our previous work [19]. This point could be concluded that the higher concentration of initial reagents results in higher primary seed generation in solution. The increasing of primary seed generation leads to lower thickness of the nanorods.

Thermo gravimetric (TG) and differential thermal analyses (DTA) of compound 1 show that the crystalline sample is stable up to 230 °C (Fig. 8), at which temperature pyrolyze of compound 1 organic part starts up to 390 °C in one step with an exothermic effect at 352 °C and mass loss of 61.2% (calcd 60.1% for removal of py-4-c− ligand). Mass loss calculations of the end residue and XRD pattern of the final decomposition product (Fig. 4c), shows the formation of metallic silver.

Figure 4c also attributed to the XRD pattern of the residue obtained from calcination of compound 1 nanorods at 823 K. The obtained pattern match with the standard pattern of cubic silver with the lattice parameters (a = 4.0862 Å and z = 4) which are close to the reported values (JCPDS card number 04-0783). SEM image (Fig. 9, up) of the residue obtained from calcination of compound 1 nanorods at 823 K shows that spongy metallic silver was formed. Thermal decomposition of compound 1 nanorods with 0.15 M concentration of initial reagent was done [37]. XRD pattern of the residue (Fig. 4c), shows that the resulting residue was cubic silver with the lattice parameters mentioned above. SEM image of the resulting residue shows the formation of silver nanoparticles with the diameter distribution of 50-95 nm and the average diameter of about 75 nm (Figs. 9, 10). A comparison between our previous works on silver(I) coordination polymers with this work shows that AgI coordination polymers have tendency to form AgI coordination polymer nanorods. For example one-dimensional AgI coordination polymer with triphenyl acetate [45], two-dimensional AgI coordination polymer with diphenyl acetate [20] or three-dimensional AgI coordination polymer with pyridine-4-carboxylate (this work), all form AgI coordination polymer nanorods. In this work, we obtained similar result from another 3D coordination polymer with no argentophilic interactions as a chain, grid or network in the compound 1 structure. As it could be observed from Fig. 1, silver atoms are separated from each other and surrounded with aromatic pyridine rings. These aromatic pyridine rings could be considered as a template to fabricate silver nanoparticles [46].

Conclusions

Nanorods of interpenetrated 3D coordination polymer with thickness distribution of 200–450 nm were synthesized by sonochemical process. Calcination of the nanorods at 823 K result in formation agglomerated metallic silver. In order to preparation silver nanostructures two other techniques was used. Silver nanoparticles with the average diameter of 75 nm prepared from thermal decomposition oleic acid (OA). Probably we could conclude that silver nanoparticles are obtained from 2D or 3D coordination polymer with no argentophilic interactions as a chain, grid or network in the resulting structure.

Supplementary Material

Complete bond lengths and angles, co-ordinates and displacement parameters have been deposited at Cambridge Crystallography Data Center. Supplementary data are available from the CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK on request, quoting the deposition number 772904 for compound 1.

Double distilled water was used to prepare aqueous solutions. An ultrasonic bath (Tecna 6; 50-60 Hz and 0.138 KW) was used for ultrasonic irradiation. Melting points were measured on an Electrothermal 9100 apparatus and were uncorrected. Microanalyses were carried out using a Heraeus CHN-O-Rapid analyzer. IR spectra were recorded using Perkin-Elmer 597 and Nicolet 510P spectrophotometers. The thermal behavior was measured with a PL-STA 1500 apparatus between 35 and 600 °C in a static nitrogen atmosphere. Crystallographic measurements were made using a Bruker APEX area-detector diffractometer. The intensity data were collected using graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (wavelength = 0.71073 Å). The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2. Structure solution and refinement were accomplished using SHELXL-97 program packages [38]. The molecular structure plot and simulated XRD powder pattern based on single crystal data were prepared using Mercury software [39]. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed using a Philips X'pert diffractometer with monochromatized Cu-kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). The samples were characterized by a scanning electron microscope with gold coating.Synthesis of [Ag2(μ2-py-4-c)2]n (1) and Preparation of Its Single CrystalsIn CH3CN (20 mL) pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (0.246 g, 2 mmol) was mixed and stirred with a solution of KOH (0.114 g, 2 mmol) in H2O (3 mL) to form a clear solution. Addition of AgNO3 (0.340 g, 2 mmol) in CH3CN (5 mL) produced a clear solution. The resulting solution was stirred for 2 h and then allowed to stand for several days in the dark at room temperature to evaporate the solvent and form crystals. Suitable brown crystals for single crystal X-ray analysis were washed with acetone and air dried, d.p. = 230 °C, Yield: 0.550 g (68% based on final product). IR (selected bands; in cm-1): 670s, 688s, 761s, 830w, 864w, 1028w, 1053w, 1144w, 1228s, 1282s, 1365vs, 1413s, 1546s, 1604s and 1729s. Anal. calcd. (%) for C12H8Ag2N2O4: C, 35.47; H, 1.97; N, 6.90; found (%): C, 34.85; H, 2.08; N, 6.72.Synthesis of [Ag2(μ2-py-4-c)2]n Nanorods by Sonochemical ProcessTo prepare nanostructures of compound 1 by sonochemical process, an ultrasonic bath with different concentrations of metal and ligand solutions (0.05, 0.10 and 0.15 M) were used. The mixture was subjected to a power level of 0.138 KW for 1 h. To the prepared ligand (Kpy-4-c) solution in double distilled water (50 mL), a proper volume of aqueous AgNO3 solution (50 mL) was added drop-wise under ultrasonic irradiation. The precipitate was filtered, washed with double distilled water and then dried; Found (%): C, 35.82; H, 1.89; N, 7.02%). IR (selected bands; in cm-1): 671s, 686s, 763s, 830w, 865w, 1027w, 1055w, 1144w, 1229s, 1282s, 1365vs, 1414s, 1548s, 1601s and 1731s. To obtain silver nanostructures, compound 1 nanorods was calcinated at 823 K in a furnace and air atmosphere for 5 h.Synthesis of Silver Nanoparticles by Thermal Decomposition in Oleic Acid as a SurfactantTo prepare silver nanoparticles in oleic acid (OA), compound 1 nanorods (406 mg, 1.0 mmol) was dispersed in OA (8 mL, 25 mmol) to form a homogenous emulsion. This solution was degassed for 15 min and then heated to 543 K for 1 h in an electric furnace. A black precipitate was formed. A small amount of toluene and a large excess of EtOH was added to the reaction solution. The metallic silver was separated by centrifugation and washed with EtOH.Results and DiscussionStructure DescriptionScheme 1 shows the reaction between silver(I) nitrate and pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (Hpy-4-c) by two different methods. The reaction between pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (Hpy-4-c) and silver(I) nitrate provided a crystalline material with the general formula [Ag2(μ2-py-4-c)2]n (1). Structure determination of compound 1 by X-ray crystallography (Tables 1, 2) showed the complex to be a novel interpenetrated three-dimensional polymer (Fig. 1). Two types of silver atoms exist in compound 1; three-coordinate Ag1 atoms with disordered T-shape AgO2N coordination sphere and two-coordinate Ag2 atoms with linear AgN2 coordination sphere (Fig. 2, up and middle). The py-4-c- ligand acts as a μ2-bridging ligand where one oxygen atom of carboxylate group and the pyridine nitrogen atom of this ligand coordinate to two silver atoms (Fig. 2, down). The structure was analyzed for close Ag⋅⋅⋅O and Ag⋅⋅⋅H secondary interactions. It appears that Ag1 atoms in compound 1 have two close contacts with O1 and O2 oxygen atoms (Ag1-O1 = 3.148 and Ag1-O2 = 3.088 Ǻ) and Ag2 atoms have also two weak secondary interactions with O2 atoms (Ag2-O2 = 2.824 Ǻ). The closest Ag-O interaction in compound 1 are longer than the Ag-O distances in similar complexes (i.e., 2.248(4), 2.279(5), 2.408(2), 2.576(2) and 2.639(2) Ǻ) [40-43] and shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radius of Ag and O (3.24 Ǻ) (van der Waals radius of Ag and O are 1.72 and 1.52 Å respectively, see [44]). On the other hand it appears that the silver ions may be involved in Ag⋅⋅⋅H-C interactions between the silver atoms and the hydrogen atoms of the py-4-c- ligand (Fig. 2, up and middle). Ag1 with a Ag(1)-H(8) distance of 2.781 Å and Ag2 with two Ag(2)-H(4) distances of 2.749 Å. The reported M⋅⋅⋅H distances for silver involved agostic interactions are 2.823, 2.706, 2.657, 2.776, 2.731 and 2.585 Ǻ [15-17]. Thus Ag2 atoms in compound 1 with linear AgN2 coordination sphere have four secondary interactions in the equatorial plane, finally forming approximately octahedral arrangement around AgI ion (Fig. 2, middle). Figure 3, up and down show the structure of compound 1 along the crystallographic b and c axis, respectively. As could be observed from these figures compound 1 has some vacant pores which may be initially thought that compound 1 is a porous coordination polymer, but more structural considerations indicate that these pores are occupied by other interpenetrating networks, result in a completely packed coordination polymer with no vacant sites.Figure 4a shows the simulated XRD pattern from single crystal X-ray data of the compound 1 and Fig. 4b shows the XRD pattern of a typical sample of [Ag2(μ2-py-4-c)2]n (1) prepared by sonochemical process. Acceptable match, with slight difference in 2θ, were observed between the simulated from single-crystal X-ray data pattern (Fig. 4a) and its from the experimental powder X-ray diffraction pattern for nanostructures obtained by sonochemical process (Fig. 4b). The results of XRD powder study indicate that the experimental data are in good agreement with the simulated XRD powder pattern based on single crystal data, hence the obtained compound is as a mono-phase. The morphology and size of the samples prepared by sonochemical process were investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Figures 5, 6 and 7 indicate the original morphology of the nanorods prepared by sonochemical process. The corresponding particle size distribution histogram of these nanorods could be observed in Figs. 5, 6 and 7. As could be observed from these figures, when concentration increases from 0.05 M (Fig. 5) to 0.15 M (Fig. 7), smaller nanorods with the average diameter of 2.212 μm, 626 nm and 239 nm was formed. This phenomenon was also observed in our previous work [19]. This point could be concluded that the higher concentration of initial reagents results in higher primary seed generation in solution. The increasing of primary seed generation leads to lower thickness of the nanorods.Thermo gravimetric (TG) and differential thermal analyses (DTA) of compound 1 show that the crystalline sample is stable up to 230 °C (Fig. 8), at which temperature pyrolyze of compound 1 organic part starts up to 390 °C in one step with an exothermic effect at 352 °C and mass loss of 61.2% (calcd 60.1% for removal of py-4-c- ligand). Mass loss calculations of the end residue and XRD pattern of the final decomposition product (Fig. 4c), shows the formation of metallic silver.Figure 4c also attributed to the XRD pattern of the residue obtained from calcination of compound 1 nanorods at 823 K. The obtained pattern match with the standard pattern of cubic silver with the lattice parameters (a = 4.0862 Å and z = 4) which are close to the reported values (JCPDS card number 04-0783). SEM image (Fig. 9, up) of the residue obtained from calcination of compound 1 nanorods at 823 K shows that spongy metallic silver was formed. Thermal decomposition of compound 1 nanorods with 0.15 M concentration of initial reagent was done [37]. XRD pattern of the residue (Fig. 4c), shows that the resulting residue was cubic silver with the lattice parameters mentioned above. SEM image of the resulting residue shows the formation of silver nanoparticles with the diameter distribution of 50-95 nm and the average diameter of about 75 nm (Figs. 9, 10). A comparison between our previous works on silver(I) coordination polymers with this work shows that AgI coordination polymers have tendency to form AgI coordination polymer nanorods. For example one-dimensional AgI coordination polymer with triphenyl acetate [45], two-dimensional AgI coordination polymer with diphenyl acetate [20] or three-dimensional AgI coordination polymer with pyridine-4-carboxylate (this work), all form AgI coordination polymer nanorods. In this work, we obtained similar result from another 3D coordination polymer with no argentophilic interactions as a chain, grid or network in the compound 1 structure. As it could be observed from Fig. 1, silver atoms are separated from each other and surrounded with aromatic pyridine rings. These aromatic pyridine rings could be considered as a template to fabricate silver nanoparticles [46].ConclusionsNanorods of interpenetrated 3D coordination polymer with thickness distribution of 200-450 nm were synthesized by sonochemical process. Calcination of the nanorods at 823 K result in formation agglomerated metallic silver. In order to preparation silver nanostructures two other techniques was used. Silver nanoparticles with the average diameter of 75 nm prepared from thermal decomposition oleic acid (OA). Probably we could conclude that silver nanoparticles are obtained from 2D or 3D coordination polymer with no argentophilic interactions as a chain, grid or network in the resulting structure.Supplementary MaterialComplete bond lengths and angles, co-ordinates and displacement parameters have been deposited at Cambridge Crystallography Data Center. elements.content: Nanorods of the three-dimensional coordination polymer, [Ag2(μ2-py-4-c)2]n (1) [py-4-c− = pyridine-4-carboxylate], have been synthesized by sonochemical process. The single-crystal X-ray data of compound 1 shows the formation of a 3D interpenetrated silver(I) coordination polymer, which has agostic interactions around the silver(I) ions and two types of AgI ions with O2NAg1···O2H, N2Ag2···O2H2 coordination spheres. Silver nanoparticles were fabricated from thermal decomposition of 1 nanorods. These nanostructures were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The thermal stability of 1 was studied by thermo gravimetric (TG) and differential thermal (DT) analysis.

Abstract

Nanorods of the three-dimensional coordination polymer, [Ag2(μ2-py-4-c)2]n (1) [py-4-c- = pyridine-4-carboxylate], have been synthesized by sonochemical process. The single-crystal X-ray data of compound 1 shows the formation of a 3D interpenetrated silver(I) coordination polymer, which has agostic interactions around the silver(I) ions and two types of AgI ions with O2NAg1⋅⋅⋅O2H, N2Ag2⋅⋅⋅O2H2 coordination spheres. Silver nanoparticles were fabricated from thermal decomposition of 1 nanorods. These nanostructures were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The thermal stability of 1 was studied by thermo gravimetric (TG) and differential thermal (DT) analysis.

elements.content: Coordination polymers are a very important topic of modern solid-state chemistry. Especially porous compounds like MOF-5 [1], MIL-53 [2] or HKUST-1 [3] have attracted attention due to their potential as heterogeneous catalysts or adsorbents for gases like hydrogen. Besides porosity, there are also attractive aspects of non-porous coordination polymers such as magnetic, luminescent, vaporochromism or conducting properties, to name a few [4–6]. Coordination polymers offer significant advantages over conventional molecular compounds due to very low solubility in conventional solvents and much higher thermal stability. They also have applications as sensors, organic light emitting diodes and full-colored LCD displays [7].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers are a very important topic of modern solid-state chemistry. Especially porous compounds like MOF-5 [1], MIL-53 [2] or HKUST-1 [3] have attracted attention due to their potential as heterogeneous catalysts or adsorbents for gases like hydrogen. Besides porosity, there are also attractive aspects of non-porous coordination polymers such as magnetic, luminescent, vaporochromism or conducting properties, to name a few [4-6]. Coordination polymers offer significant advantages over conventional molecular compounds due to very low solubility in conventional solvents and much higher thermal stability. They also have applications as sensors, organic light emitting diodes and full-colored LCD displays [7].

elements.content: Among the polymeric coinage d10 metal complexes, silver(I) coordination polymers have received much attention because silver(I) shows a tendency to form coordination polymers with unique metal–carbon [8–12] and metal–metal [13, 14] interactions. However, agostic (Ag···H–C) interactions are rare [15–17]. Over the past decade, several coordination polymeric networks of Ag+ have been synthesized and investigated. In contrast, examples of nano-scale structures of Ag+ coordination polymers are scarce [18–20]. Thus, their preparation is desirable in order to tailor their physical and chemical properties [21]. On the other hand, metallic silver has been extensively used in a variety of applications; e.g., catalysis, electronics, photonics, photography, biology and medical science, due to its unique properties. For example, silver has the highest electrical conductivity, thermal conductivity and reflectivity of all metals [22]. It is also well known that Tl+ and Ag+ compounds are similar in structure and chemical properties [23]. As a continuation of our previous studies on supramolecular compounds of these metal centers [24–34] and to have a comparison between coordination modes of these metal centers with similar ligands, we wish to report a three-dimensional coordination polymer of Ag+ with a pyridine-4-carboxylate (py-4-c−) ligand. In addition to the synthesis and characterization of a three-dimensional Ag+ nano-coordination polymer (NCP) of pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (Hpy-4-c) by the sonochemical process [19, 20, 35, 36], silver nanoparticles were fabricated by thermal decomposition in oleic acid (OA) [37].

Experimental

Materials and Physical Techniques

All reagents for synthesis and analysis were commercially available and used as received. Double distilled water was used to prepare aqueous solutions. An ultrasonic bath (Tecna 6; 50-60 Hz and 0.138 KW) was used for ultrasonic irradiation. Melting points were measured on an Electrothermal 9100 apparatus and were uncorrected. Microanalyses were carried out using a Heraeus CHN-O-Rapid analyzer. IR spectra were recorded using Perkin-Elmer 597 and Nicolet 510P spectrophotometers. The thermal behavior was measured with a PL-STA 1500 apparatus between 35 and 600 °C in a static nitrogen atmosphere. Crystallographic measurements were made using a Bruker APEX area-detector diffractometer. The intensity data were collected using graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (wavelength = 0.71073 Å). The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2. Structure solution and refinement were accomplished using SHELXL-97 program packages [38]. The molecular structure plot and simulated XRD powder pattern based on single crystal data were prepared using Mercury software [39]. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed using a Philips X'pert diffractometer with monochromatized Cu-kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). The samples were characterized by a scanning electron microscope with gold coating.

Synthesis of [Ag2(μ2-py-4-c)2]n (1) and Preparation of Its Single Crystals

In CH3CN (20 mL) pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (0.246 g, 2 mmol) was mixed and stirred with a solution of KOH (0.114 g, 2 mmol) in H2O (3 mL) to form a clear solution. Synthesis of Silver Nanoparticles by Thermal Decomposition in Oleic Acid as a Surfactant

To prepare silver nanoparticles in oleic acid (OA), compound 1 nanorods (406 mg, 1.0 mmol) was dispersed in OA (8 mL, 25 mmol) to form a homogenous emulsion. This solution was degassed for 15 min and then heated to 543 K for 1 h in an electric furnace. A black precipitate was formed. A small amount of toluene and a large excess of EtOH was added to the reaction solution. The metallic silver was separated by centrifugation and washed with EtOH.

elements.content: Scheme 1 shows the reaction between silver(I) nitrate and pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (Hpy-4-c) by two different methods. The reaction between pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (Hpy-4-c) and silver(I) nitrate provided a crystalline material with the general formula [Ag2(μ2-py-4-c)2]n (1). Structure determination of compound 1 by X-ray crystallography (Tables 1, 2) showed the complex to be a novel interpenetrated three-dimensional polymer (Fig. 1). Two types of silver atoms exist in compound 1; three-coordinate Ag1 atoms with disordered T-shape AgO2N coordination sphere and two-coordinate Ag2 atoms with linear AgN2 coordination sphere (Fig. 2, up and middle). The py-4-c− ligand acts as a μ2-bridging ligand where one oxygen atom of carboxylate group and the pyridine nitrogen atom of this ligand coordinate to two silver atoms (Fig. 2, down). The structure was analyzed for close Ag···O and Ag···H secondary interactions. It appears that Ag1 atoms in compound 1 have two close contacts with O1 and O2 oxygen atoms (Ag1–O1 = 3.148 and Ag1–O2 = 3.088 Ǻ) and Ag2 atoms have also two weak secondary interactions with O2 atoms (Ag2–O2 = 2.824 Ǻ). The closest Ag–O interaction in compound 1 are longer than the Ag–O distances in similar complexes (i.e., 2.248(4), 2.279(5), 2.408(2), 2.576(2) and 2.639(2) Ǻ) [40–43] and shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radius of Ag and O (3.24 Ǻ) (van der Waals radius of Ag and O are 1.72 and 1.52 Å respectively, see [44]). On the other hand it appears that the silver ions may be involved in Ag···H–C interactions between the silver atoms and the hydrogen atoms of the py-4-c− ligand (Fig. 2, up and middle). Ag1 with a Ag(1)–H(8) distance of 2.781 Å and Ag2 with two Ag(2)–H(4) distances of 2.749 Å. The reported M···H distances for silver involved agostic interactions are 2.823, 2.706, 2.657, 2.776, 2.731 and 2.585 Ǻ [15–17]. Thus Ag2 atoms in compound 1 with linear AgN2 coordination sphere have four secondary interactions in the equatorial plane, finally forming approximately octahedral arrangement around AgI ion (Fig. 2, middle). Figure 3, up and down show the structure of compound 1 along the crystallographic b and c axis, respectively. As could be observed from these figures compound 1 has some vacant pores which may be initially thought that compound 1 is a porous coordination polymer, but more structural considerations indicate that these pores are occupied by other interpenetrating networks, result in a completely packed coordination polymer with no vacant sites.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Description

Scheme 1 shows the reaction between silver(I) nitrate and pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (Hpy-4-c) by two different methods. The reaction between pyridine-4-carboxylic acid (Hpy-4-c) and silver(I) nitrate provided a crystalline material with the general formula [Ag2(μ2-py-4-c)2]n (1). Structure determination of compound 1 by X-ray crystallography (Tables 1, 2) showed the complex to be a novel interpenetrated three-dimensional polymer (Fig. 1). Two types of silver atoms exist in compound 1; three-coordinate Ag1 atoms with disordered T-shape AgO2N coordination sphere and two-coordinate Ag2 atoms with linear AgN2 coordination sphere (Fig. 2, up and middle). The py-4-c- ligand acts as a μ2-bridging ligand where one oxygen atom of carboxylate group and the pyridine nitrogen atom of this ligand coordinate to two silver atoms (Fig. 2, down). The structure was analyzed for close Ag⋅⋅⋅O and Ag⋅⋅⋅H secondary interactions. It appears that Ag1 atoms in compound 1 have two close contacts with O1 and O2 oxygen atoms (Ag1-O1 = 3.148 and Ag1-O2 = 3.088 Ǻ) and Ag2 atoms have also two weak secondary interactions with O2 atoms (Ag2-O2 = 2.824 Ǻ). The closest Ag-O interaction in compound 1 are longer than the Ag-O distances in similar complexes (i.e., 2.248(4), 2.279(5), 2.408(2), 2.576(2) and 2.639(2) Ǻ) [40-43] and shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radius of Ag and O (3.24 Ǻ) (van der Waals radius of Ag and O are 1.72 and 1.52 Å respectively, see [44]). On the other hand it appears that the silver ions may be involved in Ag⋅⋅⋅H-C interactions between the silver atoms and the hydrogen atoms of the py-4-c- ligand (Fig. 2, up and middle). Ag1 with a Ag(1)-H(8) distance of 2.781 Å and Ag2 with two Ag(2)-H(4) distances of 2.749 Å. The reported M⋅⋅⋅H distances for silver involved agostic interactions are 2.823, 2.706, 2.657, 2.776, 2.731 and 2.585 Ǻ [15-17]. Thus Ag2 atoms in compound 1 with linear AgN2 coordination sphere have four secondary interactions in the equatorial plane, finally forming approximately octahedral arrangement around AgI ion (Fig. 2, middle). Figure 3, up and down show the structure of compound 1 along the crystallographic b and c axis, respectively. As could be observed from these figures compound 1 has some vacant pores which may be initially thought that compound 1 is a porous coordination polymer, but more structural considerations indicate that these pores are occupied by other interpenetrating networks, result in a completely packed coordination polymer with no vacant sites.

elements.content: Figure 4a shows the simulated XRD pattern from single crystal X-ray data of the compound 1 and Fig. 4b shows the XRD pattern of a typical sample of [Ag2(μ2-py-4-c)2]n (1) prepared by sonochemical process. Acceptable match, with slight difference in 2θ, were observed between the simulated from single-crystal X-ray data pattern (Fig. 4a) and its from the experimental powder X-ray diffraction pattern for nanostructures obtained by sonochemical process (Fig. 4b). The results of XRD powder study indicate that the experimental data are in good agreement with the simulated XRD powder pattern based on single crystal data, hence the obtained compound is as a mono-phase. The morphology and size of the samples prepared by sonochemical process were investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Figures 5, 6 and 7 indicate the original morphology of the nanorods prepared by sonochemical process. The corresponding particle size distribution histogram of these nanorods could be observed in Figs. 5, 6 and 7. As could be observed from these figures, when concentration increases from 0.05 M (Fig. 5) to 0.15 M (Fig. 7), smaller nanorods with the average diameter of 2.212 μm, 626 nm and 239 nm was formed. This phenomenon was also observed in our previous work [19]. This point could be concluded that the higher concentration of initial reagents results in higher primary seed generation in solution. The increasing of primary seed generation leads to lower thickness of the nanorods.

elements.content: Thermo gravimetric (TG) and differential thermal analyses (DTA) of compound 1 show that the crystalline sample is stable up to 230 °C (Fig. 8), at which temperature pyrolyze of compound 1 organic part starts up to 390 °C in one step with an exothermic effect at 352 °C and mass loss of 61.2% (calcd 60.1% for removal of py-4-c− ligand). Mass loss calculations of the end residue and XRD pattern of the final decomposition product (Fig. 4c), shows the formation of metallic silver.

elements.content: Figure 4c also attributed to the XRD pattern of the residue obtained from calcination of compound 1 nanorods at 823 K. The obtained pattern match with the standard pattern of cubic silver with the lattice parameters (a = 4.0862 Å and z = 4) which are close to the reported values (JCPDS card number 04-0783). SEM image (Fig. 9, up) of the residue obtained from calcination of compound 1 nanorods at 823 K shows that spongy metallic silver was formed. Thermal decomposition of compound 1 nanorods with 0.15 M concentration of initial reagent was done [37]. XRD pattern of the residue (Fig. 4c), shows that the resulting residue was cubic silver with the lattice parameters mentioned above. SEM image of the resulting residue shows the formation of silver nanoparticles with the diameter distribution of 50-95 nm and the average diameter of about 75 nm (Figs. 9, 10). A comparison between our previous works on silver(I) coordination polymers with this work shows that AgI coordination polymers have tendency to form AgI coordination polymer nanorods. For example one-dimensional AgI coordination polymer with triphenyl acetate [45], two-dimensional AgI coordination polymer with diphenyl acetate [20] or three-dimensional AgI coordination polymer with pyridine-4-carboxylate (this work), all form AgI coordination polymer nanorods. In this work, we obtained similar result from another 3D coordination polymer with no argentophilic interactions as a chain, grid or network in the compound 1 structure. As it could be observed from Fig. 1, silver atoms are separated from each other and surrounded with aromatic pyridine rings. These aromatic pyridine rings could be considered as a template to fabricate silver nanoparticles [46].

Thermal decomposition of compound 1 nanorods with 0.15 M concentration of initial reagent was done [37]. XRD pattern of the residue (Fig. 4c), shows that the resulting residue was cubic silver with the lattice parameters mentioned above. SEM image of the resulting residue shows the formation of silver nanoparticles with the diameter distribution of 50-95 nm and the average diameter of about 75 nm (Figs. 9, 10). A comparison between our previous works on silver(I) coordination polymers with this work shows that AgI coordination polymers have tendency to form AgI coordination polymer nanorods. For example one-dimensional AgI coordination polymer with triphenyl acetate [45], two-dimensional AgI coordination polymer with diphenyl acetate [20] or three-dimensional AgI coordination polymer with pyridine-4-carboxylate (this work), all form AgI coordination polymer nanorods. As it could be observed from Fig. 1, silver atoms are separated from each other and surrounded with aromatic pyridine rings. These aromatic pyridine rings could be considered as a template to fabricate silver nanoparticles [46].

elements.content: Nanorods of interpenetrated 3D coordination polymer with thickness distribution of 200–450 nm were synthesized by sonochemical process. Calcination of the nanorods at 823 K result in formation agglomerated metallic silver. In order to preparation silver nanostructures two other techniques was used. Silver nanoparticles with the average diameter of 75 nm prepared from thermal decomposition oleic acid (OA). Probably we could conclude that silver nanoparticles are obtained from 2D or 3D coordination polymer with no argentophilic interactions as a chain, grid or network in the resulting structure.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Nanorods of interpenetrated 3D coordination polymer with thickness distribution of 200-450 nm were synthesized by sonochemical process. Calcination of the nanorods at 823 K result in formation agglomerated metallic silver. In order to preparation silver nanostructures two other techniques was used. Silver nanoparticles with the average diameter of 75 nm prepared from thermal decomposition oleic acid (OA). Probably we could conclude that silver nanoparticles are obtained from 2D or 3D coordination polymer with no argentophilic interactions as a chain, grid or network in the resulting structure.
